docs.lead_paragraph: When pharmaceutical companies recruit sick people for studies of experimental drugs, what are the companies' obligations to the patients? And once people sign up, accepting risk but hoping for benefit, receiving free medical care and drugs, what do they owe to science, to future patients who may be helped by the research and to the company that may profit from it? Last year, Gail Ogden, 55, of Westmoreland, Kan., confronted those questions firsthand when her discovery that she had chronic hepatitis C, a viral disease of the liver, led her into the maze of modern experimental medicine.

headline.main: Patient or Guinea Pig? Dilemma of Clinical Trials

docs.abstract: Clinical trials for Rebetron, Schering-Plough's treatment for hepatitis C, illustrate the ethical questions that arise in tests of experimental drugs, including what obligations the pharmaceutical companies have to the patients they recruit and what obligations those patients have to science, to future patients who may be helped by research and to the company that may profit from it; Gail Ogden, who is three months into the 48-week trial, is very unhappy that data on her viral load is being withheld from her and her doctor; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1997, Congress and the Clinton Administration agreed on a five-year plan to balance the Federal budget. In 1998, they watched in surprise as the deficit disappeared ahead of schedule and the nation entered what should be a long era of surpluses. In 1999, Congress and the Administration will debate in earnest for the first time what to do with the fiscal windfall, which the Congressional Budget Office estimates should total $1.55 trillion over the next decade.

docs.lead_paragraph: You would think that after last year's more than $2.5 trillion in announced mergers worldwide -- the largest on record -- corporate executives might take 1999 off. Think again. With the stock market for the most part continuing its upward march, investors can expect even more mergers in the next 12 months. But unlike last year, when mergers were concentrated primarily in the telecommunications, banking and insurance industries, the frenzy this year will spread to other industries as well, merger professionals say. Even more international combinations are expected in the months ahead, along with a shift in activity to include industrial companies as well as increased activity in the burgeoning high-technology industry.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will announce a $6 billion package of tax and budget proposals on Monday to help provide long-term care for people with chronic illnesses or disabilities, Administration officials said today. The proposals represent the most ambitious effort to deal with the long-term care needs of the elderly since the collapse of Mr. Clinton's plan to guarantee health insurance for all Americans in 1994.

docs.lead_paragraph: It might seem churlish to find fault with a best-in-a-generation economy. Unemployment and inflation rates are at record lows, and low-paid workers are, for the first time in decades, receiving wage increases that outpace price increases. But despite the benefits of a temporarily buoyant economy, deep-seated problems remain. Frank Levy, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, notes that the best time to tackle problems is when the economy is flush. He points to increasing inequality at a time of stagnating wages in his new book, ''The New Dollars and Dreams'' (Russell Sage Foundation, 1998). Borrowing a phrase from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Mr. Levy warns against ''defining deviancy down -- accepting economic outcomes as normal today that would have been seen as pathological 10 or 20 years ago.''

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I write in response to Dr. Lomazow's essay, ''Point of Procedure'' ( Soapbox, Dec. 20), which criticized the state's new insurance regulations for treating those injured in car accidents. I am a retired board-certified orthopedic surgeon. I practiced in New Jersey for 36 years and treated or evaluated thousands of automobile-accident patients. I have absolutely no doubt that a good number of accident patients have received unnecessary protracted medical care by physicians and chiropractors. In addition, insurance carriers, when attempting to adjudicate or settle cases, have compounded this situation by often measuring the degree of permanent injury by the amount of medical treatment, which fosters prolonged treatment. Therefore, it is essential (especially in neck and low back patients) that all treatment be subject to review after four weeks. Declining of treatment should be reviewed, if requested, by unbiased specialists, who must be required to put their reasoning in writing. That way, if a reviewer justifies, for example, more months of medical treatment or chiropractic manipulation, then academic specialists have something into which they can sink their teeth when they make evaluations later.

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was a time not so long ago when the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital on East 64th Street was as chic a destination for Christmas vacation as St. Barts or Telluride. That is where many teen-aged girls would disappear during school holidays to get the ethnic bumps on their noses smoothed out. So crowded were the operating rooms at this time of year, recalled Dr. Gerald H. Pitman, a plastic surgeon, that he would set out 20 sets of rhinoplasty instruments in the morning and run out before the day was done.

docs.lead_paragraph: FROM the time it opened in 1905, the Gotham Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street -- now the Peninsula New York -- played second fiddle to the 1904 St. Regis across the street. But the former Gotham -- bankrupted in 1908 after it failed to get a liquor license -- has reopened after a gut renovation and is aiming for parity with its more famous neighbor. In 1902, while the St. Regis was still under construction, a group headed by Henry R. Hoyt bought the plot across from it, the southwest corner of 55th and Fifth. The initial concept for what became the Gotham was a residential hotel for those New Yorkers who were tired of maintaining a city house.
